quoteLast: , six long-exposure, wide-angle photographs of the dark side of Jupiter had been scheduled to search for aurorae and lightning. The spacecraft was 1 450 000 kilometers from Jupiter and about two degrees below the equatorial plane.
title: Voyage to Jupiter
author: Morrison, David, 1940-; Samz, Jane

quoteFirst: Battle Fleet before deployment could be effected. So at
quoteLast: a signal was made to the Battle Fleet to form line of battle on the port wing column, on a course south-east by east, it being assumed that the course of the enemy was approximately the same as that of our battle cruisers.
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: The accuracy of the “plot” is therefore confirmed, so far as confirmation is possible. It appears certain that between about 6.0 P.M. and
quoteLast: the German battle cruisers turned 16 points towards their Battle Fleet, and again turned 16 points to their original course. This is borne out by observations on board the _Warrior_, which ship was being engaged by the _starboard_ guns of enemy vessels.
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: From about 6.10 P.M. onwards they had come under fire of guns of heavy calibre from the enemy’s battle cruisers, but Sir Robert Arbuthnot, as gallant and determined an officer as ever lived, was evidently bent on finishing off his opponent, and held on, probably not realising in the gathering smoke and mist that the enemy’s heavy ships were at fairly close range. At about
quoteLast: the _Defence_ was hit by two salvoes in quick succession, which caused her magazines to blow up and the ship disappeared. The loss of so valuable an officer as Sir Robert Arbuthnot and so splendid a ship’s company as the officers and men of the _Defence_ was a heavy blow.
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: We left the 3rd Battle Cruiser Squadron at about 6.10 P.M. at the termination of their engagement with enemy light cruisers, turning to avoid torpedoes fired at them. At about this time Rear-Admiral Hood sighted the _Lion_ and the 1st Battle Cruiser Squadron, and at about
quoteLast: hoisted the signal to his squadron to form single line ahead, and turned to take station ahead of the _Lion_ and to engage the hostile battle cruisers, which at 6.20 P.M. were sighted at a range of 8,600 yards.
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteLast: _Defence_ and _Warrior_ were observed passing down between the British and German Battle Fleets under a very heavy fire. _Defence_ was seen to blow up and _Warrior_ passed to the rear disabled.
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: He opened his eyes at times, and until within twenty minutes before his death he seemed to recognise me. At
quoteLast: , he rendered up his spirit into the arms of death in his sleep.
title: My Memoirs, Vol. VI, 1832 to 1833
author: Dumas, Alexandre, 1802-1870; Waller, E. M. (Emily Mary) [Translator]

quoteLast: they were both dressed, and Simeon was showing Arthur that Simeon alone knew how to pack a trunk. At twenty minutes past six the trunk was packed, locked and strapped.
title: The Matador of the Five Towns and Other Stories
author: Bennett, Arnold, 1867-1931

quoteFirst: The first official information of the disaster was the message from Captain Haddock, of the Olympic, received by the White Star Line at
quoteLast: , Monday, April 15. In the face of this information a message reporting the Titanic being towed to Halifax was sent to Representative J. A. Hughes, at Huntington, W. Va., at 7.51 P. M. that day. The message was delivered to the Western Union office in the same building as the White Star Line offices.
title: Sinking of the Titanic and Great Sea Disasters
author: Marshall, Logan, 1884-1937 [Editor]

quoteLast: _Defence_ and _Warrior_ were observed passing down between the British and German Battle Fleets under a very heavy fire. _Defence_ disappeared, and _Warrior_ passed to rear disabled.
title: World's War Events, Vol. II
author: Reynolds, Francis J. (Francis Joseph), 1867-1937 [Editor]; Churchill, Allen L. (Allen Leon), 1873- [Editor]
